claim_object.outcome_concept: Asymmetric belief updating (motivated reasoning): subjects in the No-Resolution treatment underreact to bad news relative to Bayesian benchmark, indicating motivated beliefs when future uncertainty will not be resolved
claim_object.treatment_concept: Comparison of belief updating slopes (good vs bad news) across Resolution vs No-Resolution treatments. The focal coefficient is the slope of belief_adjustment on bayes_belief_adjustment for bad news in the No-Resolution treatment.
claim_object.estimand_concept: OLS coefficient of belief_adjustment on bayes_belief_adjustment, measuring responsiveness to Bayesian updating benchmark, split by treatment and signal type
claim_object.target_population: Laboratory subjects (200 university students) in a between-subject IQ-test belief experiment

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col2-NoRes-Bad
baseline_specs.notes: Main claim: coefficient near zero = underreaction to bad news in No-Resolution

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col3-NoRes-DiD
baseline_specs.notes: Diff-in-diff within No-Resolution: interaction captures asymmetry

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col5-Res-Bad
baseline_specs.notes: Bad news in Resolution (contrast to No-Resolution bad news)

constraints.notes: Baseline uses 0 controls for single-signal regressions and 2 for DiD. Additional controls are pre-treatment covariates (rank, sumpoints, age, gender, prior, session) and serve only for precision, not identification, given randomization.

canonical.notes: Paper uses robust (HC1) standard errors throughout. No clustering.

variants.notes: HC3 small-sample leverage correction, useful with N=50 per cell.
Cluster at session level (randomization unit is session-level treatment assignment).

budgets.notes: Full enumeration feasible. 6 baselines x (1 baseline + ~12 RC variants) + 2 design variants x 6 cells = ~84 specs.
